Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Social exclusion as a determinant of individuation and stereotyping

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Maintaining positive social relationships is important for individuals' well being. Despite this, people often experience social exclusion (colloquially referred to as "ostracism"). The experience of social exclusion makes people feel that they do not belong and leaves them wanting to re-connect. Rather than attempting to connect with just anyone, research shows that excluded people pick certain individuals. Specifically, they focus their attention on the identification of the best and most receptive re-affiliation partners. As a result, people who are excluded, compared to those who are not, are more likely to evaluate people based on their individual characteristics and personalities -- a process called "individuation" -- rather than characteristics based on beliefs about their group memberships -- a process called "stereotyping." Three lines of research will examine the relation between social exclusion and individuation. These studies will examine several different stereotyped groups, using multiple methods of social exclusion. Specific experiments will investigate (1) the role of the desire to reconnect in producing greater individuation after exclusion, (2) the circumstances under which exclusion is more and less likely to trigger individuation, and (3) the role that social exclusion plays in maintaining stereotypes.

While extensive bodies of literature exist on social exclusion as well as the processing of group-based information such as stereotypes, the proposed research will be the first to synthesize these two areas of social psychology. Moreover, the proposed work will also further education and broaden participation of underrepresented groups in science. For instance, several undergraduate and graduate students will aid in conducting, analyzing, and disseminating the proposed research. Many of these students will come from groups traditionally underrepresented in science, such as women, racial minorities, and those from less affluent backgrounds.

Finally, research shows that exclusion can trigger aggressive responses in both the laboratory and real-world settings. Some scholars suggest that social exclusion may be a contributing factor to tragedies such as school shootings. To help prevent excluded individuals from engaging in destructive actions, the proposed research could help scientists identify ways that excluded individuals can cope positively. Though many factors likely determine which victims of exclusion cope well and which do not, one factor may concern how they subsequently think about others following exclusion. Excluded individuals who evaluate others carefully (e.g., via individuation) may cope better with exclusion by finding new friends and therefore may be less likely to lash out. Encouraging the excluded to individuate others may provide one method of fostering adaptive coping. These efforts could prove especially useful in schools where incidents of bullying and exclusion are common. Therefore, the current work may help researchers understand how individuals handle exclusion and, ultimately, could provide strategies to deploy in schools and other relevant settings to defend against exclusion's potentially damaging consequences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
At one time or another, everyone is ostracized, rejected, or socially excluded. Previous work suggests that people can cope with these experiences and pursue re-affiliation by carefully and accurately processing social information. Such careful processing may lead to effective identification of appropriate and welcoming interaction partners who could restore one’s sense of belonging.

The major goal of this project was to understand why and when social exclusion leads to a specific type of careful social-information processing: individuation – rendering judgments of others based on their idiosyncratic features – versus stereotyping – rendering judgments of others based simply on their group memberships. A stereotypic impression of another person could be accurate if the target happens to possess stereotypic attributes. But, all else being equal, impressions based on individuation should be more accurate and informative because they reflect known properties of the person.

We contend that social exclusion is one circumstance in which forming accurate impressions is crucial. Excluded individuals are in a difficult situation, having been cut-off from meaningful social connections, leaving them vulnerable to myriad negative consequences, including reduced mood and self-esteem, feelings of physical pain, and so forth. To avoid these problems, the excluded need to re-connect with others, and their attuned social-cognitive skills presumably aids in this process.

Published studies supported by this grant offered evidence consistent with our overarching prediction that exclusion triggers greater use of individuation. Some important boundary conditions were also identified. For instance, excluded individuals individuate people, but not non-social objects, presumably because non-social objects are not capable of providing affiliation. Moreover, excluded individuals appear to individuate people who seem at least minimally desirable for affiliation, but refrain from individuating people deemed unworthy of affiliation (e.g., neo-Nazis).

The grant also examined studies aimed at uncovering other boundary conditions of the effect, but the results regarding these other boundary conditions were inconclusive. We will continue investigating these issues (without NSF support) in the future.

This grant also supported numerous studies aimed at developing a measure of state desire for affiliation. We believe that such desires explain why exclusion typically prompts more individuation. However, the literature currently lacks a well-validated measurement instrument to assess such state desires for affiliation. The studies conducted to develop this instrument were described in a manuscript that is currently under review at a journal (at the time of writing this project report). In the future (without grant funding), we hope to determine whether exclusion alters state desires for affiliation and, if so, if such desires mediate the impact of exclusion on individuation or other common outcomes post exclusion.

Studies supported by the grant have been disseminated to the scientific community in a published article, a forthcoming book chapter, and potentially other articles (if accepted for publication after the end of the grant period). Moreover, the principal investigators have given numerous conference talks/posters and invited university colloquia on these findings.

Numerous undergraduate students as well as four graduate students, many of them from populations under-represented in science, have contributed to this work in meaningful ways, including programming studies, developing materials, collecting and analyzing data, presenting findings, and writing up results for publication. Thus, this grant has aided in the educational advancement and skill development of promising young scholars.

Overall, this work has uncovered important findings about how exclusion shapes the use of individuation and stereotyping, which might lead other scholars or community leaders to craft programs to aid those who have been victimized by chronic exclusion or bullying. Use of individuation by such people may help them effectively identify welcoming others in their environments who can restore their lost belonging needs.
